awd_titl_txt: Notions of Curvature and Their Role in Analysis on Metric Measure Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The sphere, a flat surface such as a flat piece of paper, and a hyperbolic surface such as a saddle behave differently from each other. On the surface of the ball curves of least length (geodesics) emanating from a point in different directions tend to not move away from each other in the short term, or at least less rapidly than in the flat surface, whereas in the saddle surface the geodesics curve away from each other rapidly. This behavior is related to the curvature of the surface, with the sphere of positive curvature, the flat surface of zero curvature, and the saddle of negative curvature. Analogs of this behavior hold in higher dimensional objects that occur in nature. Curvature plays a key role in how natural phenomena such as dissipation of heat and electricity behave, and this is true also in objects that are not as smooth as the three types described above. Such non-smooth objects occur in nature and have creases, bumps and fractal-like structure, and so the classical theory of curvature does not apply to them. The focus of this project is to use the analog of curvature developed for the non-smooth setting recently, and explore how that dictates the behavior of natural phenomena such as heat dissipation in such objects.

The goal of this project is to explore links between the notions of negative curvature of a metric space on the one hand, and nonlinear potential theory and quasiconformal mappings on the other hand. The spaces considered are equipped with a uniformly locally doubling measure supporting a uniformly local Poincare inequality. A prototype space equipped with a uniformly locally doubling measure supporting a uniformly local Poincare inequality but does not support their global analogs is the smooth hyperbolic manifold, and experience tells us that such spaces have exponential volume growth at large scales. This project is divided into three parts. In the first part of the project, the focus is the large scale negative curvature of the space (as given in optimal mass transportation) and its connections to large-scale potential theory (non-linear ``heat" energy dissipation) and hyperbolicity of ends. In the second part the aim is to construct geometric families of curves connecting pairs of points in the space when the space has lower bounded Ricci curvature in the sense of Lott and Villani. The third part of the project is to consider bounded doubling nonsmooth spaces as boundaries of Gromov-hyperbolic filling and use this perspective to study non-local potential theory and regularity of nonlocal energy minimizers on poorly pathconnected spaces. The research described herein forms a part of the program of quasiconformal classification of nonsmooth spaces. Such spaces arise in the study of smooth manifolds when considering Gromov-Hausdorff limit spaces as in the works of Cheeger, Gromov, and Perelman.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of the project was to identify the role of curvature in the theory of analysis on metric spaces.  Keeping in mind the analogs of curvature: standard model for positive curvature is given by a sphere, Euclidean spaces are the models for zero curvature, and hyperbolic (saddle-like) spaces model the behavior of spaces of negative curvature, the following roles of curvature were identified by the PI and collaborators in the process of carrying on the research for this project. The objects of study are complete metric measure spaces (objects together with a notion of distance between pairs of points in the object, such that we can also measure an analog of volume of subregions of the space) where the measure is doubling and supports a local Poincare inequality.

(1) Metric measure spaces of non-negative curvature, as embodied by a Bakry-Emery type curvature condition driving the evolution of heat equation in the metric setting, allow us to construct.analogs of nonlocal function spaces such as Besov spaces, and also sets of finite perimeter, even if the underlying metric space does not support a 1-Poincare inequality. Given that 1-Poincare inequality has been, up to this point, the tool used to study sets of finite perimeter, this outcome of the project allow us to bypass the Poincare inequality in studying sets of finite perimeter.

(2) Metric measure spaces of large-scale negative curvature, as embodied by the notion of thin triangles, are called Gromov hyperbolic spaces. It is known from the works of Bourdon, Pajot, Bonk, Schramm, Kleiner, and Saksman that every compact doubling metric space is quasisymmetrically equivalent to the boundary of a Gromov hyperbolic metric space. One of the outcomes of the project is that in fact, every doubling metric space is biLipschitz equivalent to the boundary of a uniformization of a Gromov hyperbolic space. Thus, to perform analysis on doubling metric spaces that are so badly connected that no Poincare inequality holds on the space (such as fractals including the Sierpinski carpet and the Cantor sets), the research project continued this line of investigation by constructing lifts of measures from the compact doubling space to the Gromov hyperbolic space of interest. It was discovered that the uniformization of the Gromov hyperbolic space, together with the uniformization of the lifted metric, resulted in a uniform domain with a doubling measure that supports the strongest of all the Poincare inequalities, the 1-Poincare inequality. This means that the uniformized hyperbolic space is well-connected by paths in them, and so the Dirichlet energy and other nonlinear local (Sobolev) energies are well-understood on this uniform space. In subsequent research, the PI and collaborators demonstrated that the nonlocal energies such as Besov energies on the compact doubling space arise as traces of local energies on the uniformized hyperbolic space associated with the compact space. Effectively, the hyperbolic space acts as a virtual conduit for transmission of information from one region of the compact space to another.

(3) Using the tools developed in the part of the project linking Gromov hyperbolic spaces to compact doubling spaces, the PI and collaborators proceeded to study properties of non-local (Besov) energy minimizers on doubling metric measure spaces supporting a Poincare inequality. From this subproject it was discovered that every such non-local energy minimizer arises as the trace of a harmonic function on a half-space (the Cartesian product of the metric space with the set of all positive real numbers). The half-space has all the well-connected properties exhibited by the uniformization of Gromov hyperbolic spaces as described above, and so, the PI and collaborators were able to leverage knowledge of how harmonic functions in such well-connected spaces behave and demonstrate that the non-local energy minimizers are well-behaved in the sense that they have the regularity properties of local Holder continuity and Harnack inequality.

The above three outcomes of the research undertaken for this project demonstrates the roles and impact curvature has on the behavior of functions on metric measure spaces.
